Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Experimental analysis of strain transients in a heterogeneous semi-brittle system: Implications for tectonics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tectonic motions give rise to destructive earthquakes and to enigmatic slower slip events on fault zones. Brittle behavior and friction laws that describe slip over fractured or rough fault surfaces do not account for the fact that fault zones can simultaneously break in a brittle manner and flow in a ductile way as has been observed in the geologic record. This project combines laboratory experiments and theoretical analysis on the effect a semi-brittle material can have on the mechanisms of deformation localization and slip accumulation, which may provide critical insights on the mechanics of earthquakes.

This project proposes that the wide variation in deformation speeds from earthquake to steady creep can be explained by the interaction of brittle fracturing and ductile flow in a semi-brittle material. This behavior will be explored with physical experiments using Carbopol, which exhibits both brittle and ductile deformation simultaneously. The experiments will test whether the interaction of tensional and shear fractures in a semi-brittle material leads to strain transients, or if, alternatively, the re-occurring strain transients are controlled by the strength along the shear fracture such that the formation of the fractures only appears to be concurrent with the slip. The results will be incorporated into an analytical model, which allows extrapolating the results to time scales relevant to strain transients in Earth. The work proposed here will fundamentally advance the understanding of semi-brittle deformation and its impact on strain transients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

We set out to investigate the impact of different types of fractures (opening and shear) on deformation dynamics through physical experiments on a semi-brittle material. The deformation in Earth’s crust can range from fast, seismic stick-slip motion to slow, non-seismic creep. Understanding the transition and interaction between stick-slip and creep has direct implications for seismic hazards and mitigation. The reason why we focus on semi-brittle materials is because they combine the deformation time scale associated with fractures and earthquakes and the time scale of viscoelastic deformation associated with a flowing ductile crust. Furthermore, semi-brittle behavior occurs over a wide range of temperature and pressure conditions for many mineral assemblages and might affect deformation processes from the micro to the lithospheric scale.

For this project we developed a shear machine that is suitable to record the whole spectrum of deformation, from stick-slip to creep. We use a relatively weak, gel-like material as a rock analog that has similar properties, when deformed, to rocks in the middle crust. This machine is one of a kind as it allows us to study the fracture evolution in situ during deformation. Currently this cannot be achieved with numerical methods or with rock-physics experiments. Our experiments show that the formation and interaction between opening and shear fractures can modulate the slip dynamics. Depending on the yield stress of the modeling material, we can observe deformation that is continuous, leading to a creep signal without opening of fractures (low yield stress). For higher yield stresses, we observe stick-slip motion together with the opening of mode I fractures. At an intermediate yield stress, opening and shear fractures interact and lead to slip dynamics that are between the end member cases of stick-slip and creep. We were able to demonstrate that a semi-brittle material, which can be expected throughout the middle crust, has the potential of being an important factor in the transition between stick-slip and creep. 

Broader impact:

The project provided the thesis subject and stipend for a graduate student. Furthermore, it enabled us to host seven high school students for a month long summer internship. The aim of this outreach program was to introduce students from underrepresented groups in STEM to research in geology and life at a research university. The experimental setup has been used for teaching purposes at ISU and Macalester College. In collaboration with Alan Chapman (Macalester College) we developed publicly available teaching materials that uses the experimental apparatus (https://serc.carleton.edu/NAGTWorkshops/structure/activities/189822.html).

 

Efforts supported by this grant will lead to three peer-reviewed publications and nine presentations at national and international conferences.
